The term $dqp$ in the exponent of (\ref{sch4}) renders the wavefucntion $\Psi(p,q,t)$ non-separable, and hence is responsible for electron-light entanglement when $d\neq{}0$.  Using the solution (\ref{sch4}) we can calculate the quantum expectation values of any physical observable, for example, electron momentum $\left\langle p\right\rangle(t) = \left\langle\Psi\left|p\right|\Psi\right\rangle$, electron trajectories $\left\langle x\right\rangle(t)=\left\langle\Psi\left|\hat{x}\right|\Psi\right\rangle$, electron kinetic energy $W_{e}(t)=\frac{1}{2}\left\langle p^{2}\right\rangle$, field energy $W_{\rm light}(t)=\omega\sqrt{1+\frac{\beta^{2}}{\omega}}\Big[\frac{1}{2}+\bar{N}(t)\Big]$, $\bar{N}(t)=\left\langle N \right\rangle = \left\langle\Psi\left| \hat{a}^{+}\hat{a} \right|\Psi\right\rangle$, etc. In fact from the general solution (\ref{sch4}) we can recover energy conservation, i.e. the instantaneous interaction energy of the electron is given by $W_{\text{e,int}}(t)=W_{e}(t)-W_{e}(0)=W_{\text{light}}(0)-W_{\text{light}}(t)$, where $W_{e}(0)$ is the initial kinetic energy of the electron, and $W_{\text{light}}(0)=\omega\sqrt{1+\frac{\beta^{2}}{\omega}}\Big[\frac{1}{2}+N_{0}\Big]$ is the initial energy of the light field.
